number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Some of you may recognize me and my name from my work on "Elemental: War of Magic". If you do, then you'll know that I know what I'm talking about when it comes to Stardock games.Galactic Civilizations III is the successor to the wildly popular Galactic Civilizations II. If you are familiar with Gal Civ II then you should largely know what to expect this time around. There is a multitude of options and settings, performance tweaks and graphical settings. Everything you can think of from Gal Civ II is here and improved upon. Some of the options from the expansions of Gal Civ II are missing, but, if you know Stardock and how they do things then you know those options are coming in future expansions and DLC.Being the first installment (base game) there are things that can be improved upon, again though if you know Stardock then you know these things are coming down the road. I wouldn't say they left things out on purpose, but more so because they know they have to have content for future expansions. Have no fear that some of those options you may notice that are missing from Gal Civ II WILL eventually be in Gal Civ III as well. If you'd like proof of this look at the base game (no expansions) of Gal Civ II, then look at Gal Civ II Ultimate Edition and everything that was added in between. This is a pattern with Stardock and they will follow the same pattern here.The Gal Civ series has been my favorite Space 4X strategy series since Masters of Orion 1&2. The only thing lacking in Gal Civ in my opinion is directly controllable battles, though you do still have many options when it comes to battles. What roles you design for your ships and how well you design them plays a huge part in battles, and the battles are epic and beautiful. Ground battles and invasions are a bit "bare bones" at the moment, but I can promise you this will be expanded upon with further updates and expansions as well.Moddability in Gal Civ III is Off The Charts!!! This time around basically the entire game is opened up for modding, even more so than Gal Civ II, and you don't need to be a master programmer to do it. New mods and content are being worked on as I type this and the future of Gal Civ III is as bright as the brightest star in the universe. There's nothing here not to like.If you've ever been a fan of 4X strategy games or Space strategy games then the only thing you need to be asking yourself right now is "Why haven't I bought this yet?!?!". Don't miss out on this epic gem of a game. If you only buy 1 strategy 4X this year there's no question in what you should be doing right now. Buy it, you won't be disappointed...........Why are you still reading this? You should be playing right now!!!

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												34 hours in the first week and a half. No regrets. Pros Extremely detailed - You can easily get lost in the immense detail of the game. For instance, the level of detail and complexity in ship design is amazing. Research options seem endless. The size of the map can range anywhere from just a handful of sectors to thousands of sectors in area.Beautiful - The graphics are very nice. Everything is very polished and nice to look at.Endless possibilities - This kinda goes hand-in-hand with the detail, but there are just so many choices you can make. You can create your own alien races, able to customize how they construct their civilization and interact with others. You can not only design aesthetics for your own ships, but combine modules in endless combinations to give your ship any number of strengths. I'm sure that I've only begun to scratch the surface of the possibilities in this game.Like Civilization, but way, way better - And it's in space!Super powerful uber death machines - When you start manufacturing the huge-size ships with the fully upgrades weapons, you can take on an entire fleet with one ship. Not to say that this is easy to get to. It takes quite a while to get to that point in research and manufacturing capability, but it's extremely rewarding when you do. Cons A bit buggy - I got it on release day. It has crashed inexplicably quite a few times while playing. Thankfully, the autosave is very reliable, and I only ended up losing a few turns each time. It seems that they've fixed this somewhat, but not completely.Very, very time consuming - Not necessarily a con, but it might be for some people. Do NOT get this game if you just want a quick play-through. This game takes a lot of time to get into, learn, and actually play, especially when you start moving into the larger maps.I never played the previous games in this franchise, but I love this one. Overall, I'd say it's a very good buy if you're someone who's willing to put a lot of time into a turn-based strategy game. It's like Civ on steroids, in space, with giant lasers.

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												Galactic Civilizations 3 is the latest in a series of space 4X games by Stardock. With this game really what you see is what you get- it really is a highly evolved space based version of civilisation. If you like Civilisation chances are you will love this. That being said there are both positive and negative aspects to this title which sets it apart from its brother. During this review I plan to outline those elements to help you make up your mind on this product. Full Disclosure, I have been a very long term fan of Stardock and their business practises- I backed the game at the $100 “all dlc included” level and in doing so you could say I have a vested interest in seeing this game succeed. That said, I still feel like I should be able to help you make up your mind. 	I have been following Galciv3 since it was first announced and released into early access. One of the first things someone may ask is; how much has changed since this game entered early access? Well the game has seen an entire UI, graphical and gameplay overhaul since the initial alpha stages. Generally the patches came out once ever few months and overhauled the entire game each time. I expect this to be a similar pace to what we will see when development of DLC , Expansions and Patches begins. Stardock is very transparent with their community and often lets users see content long before release during dev streams. To get a good idea of just how much has changed, try watching one of their oldest streams before watching one of their newer ones... it is night and day. 	Things are changing sure, but how is the gameplay? Well, upon starting a new game players’ have the option of customising everything similar to Civilisation. They may tweak the universe to be as hostile or peaceful as they want, crowded or sparse. Players can even design their own civilisation by choosing traits, style and AI personality. Upon starting players are given a scout ship (exploration), a colony ship (settler) and a survey ship (dedicated goodie hut finder). From here the player strives towards one of multiple goals. All the usual suspects are there in the form of Conquest, Time, Research and Diplomacy- but the game also offers alternative victory options such as influence and ascension. The maps can be any size from small 5 min blastoffs to full multi day megamatches. However if you plan on playing on the highest map size (insane) you will really need a beefy PC. Often the slightly smaller sizes of Gigantic, Immese or Excessive are much more “playable”, but they have made recent strives which have allowed me to play Insane til victory comfortably. 	So just how IS performance anyway? The first thing you need to know about GalCiv3 is that it REQUIRES a 64bit OS to play- if you do not have one you really should be barking up another tree. The game seems to use a large chunk of ram and I can imagine Ram speed being a much higher requirement then in most games. Unlike Civilisation games, GalCiv3 boasts pretty impressive multi-core management. Each AI player runs on a single core/thread until all your cores are doing something. After that deal out starts again. Turn speeds will eventually become an issue, but the release version seems much better than it was even a few days ago.  	The game is not flawless in its current state. There are bugs and the occasional tooltip error but Stardock says that they plan on supporting GalCiv3 for many years. Currently the plan is to release a series of DLC and Expansion packs slowly over the next few years along with free and sizable patches. How well they actually go with this is yet to be determined but they were generally pretty good with that during the past two GalCiv games. My biggest issue with the game at this time is more the perceived loss of character in the random events. The pictures for these events are not yet as diverse and interesting as they seemed in previous games and I often found myself selecting choices based on stats and ideological desires instead of picking what I would actually do. Another thing which personally irks me is the lack of “Wonders”. Generally there are only a small number of ‘one per galaxy’ buildings which are placed at late places in the tech tree. While in a game of Civilisation the question is “is it worth aiming for this wonder which everyone else could be aiming for”, in Galciv3 it is more like ‘oh, I must be the first person to get this tech. better build the wonder. No need to rush though, likely they have specialised in a different tech tree.’	In a first for the series Multiplayer is also included- though it is normally always best to play with someone you actually know as games could last a long time. Unfortunately the “Play by Email” option which was once common for games such as this is not possible. Multiplayer has not tarnished the familiar features though, nor has it taken centre stage. The signature Ship Designer feature is still very much in play, as is a scripted story based campaign. You can still watch your space battles in a pretty impressive (but hands off) way and you still have a (disappointingly simple) invasion screen. There are no Planet Busters currently (eg Terror Star) but they are planned for a later Expansion pack (much like in previous titles). Overall the gameplay is fluid and polished- playing the game feels much better than playing GalCiv2 did. 	Overall I would easily recommend this game, especially if you like the promise of future DLC and Expansion packs. The game is a complete, polished and next generation 4X game which presses all the right buttons for me. Galciv3 is like the Cities Skylines to the CitiesXL or Sim City... A game which is much better optimised at doing what it needs to do, capturing the essence of what people love about the genre without killing your computer. With that in mind I say bravo Stardock- and please bring on the expansions, DLC and Steam Workshop (which will be added in version 1.1).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												Probably the best sci-fi turn-based strategy game I have ever played.  I played GalCiv II before 3 was made and really enjoyed it, but it was getting on in years and it showed a little.  When I then heard that GalCiv III was in the works, I pre-purchased it here on Steam, and even tried out the Beta a bit.  It wasn't nearly complete at the time, so I put it down for a while.  Then I played a very similar game called Endless Space, and it reminded me of GalCiv, but was also missing a lot…and I do mean A LOT (don't play it, it'll only disapoint you).  So I came back to GalCiv III, thinking that it must certainly be finished by now, and I was not disapointed at all.  It is a simply wonderful game if you like extensively deep turn-based strategy and civilization-simulator games.  It has excellent customization ability, allowing you to truly create a civilization all your own, and design/build ships that are truly unique.  The campaign is also quite intriguing, and will captivate you if you take the time to thoroughly read the dialogues and experience the story.After playing again for a little while, I then went and bought all the DLC without thinking twice about it.  As I said before…not at all disapointed.  Some of the best money I've ever spent on a game.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												I had originally reviewed this game as recommended. I liked the soundtrack, the gameplay, and the look.  The most recent patch has "overhauled" (Read: dumbed down) economic management to the point that the game is just not worth playing at all. Managing the research, production, and wealth of my empire and striking a balance between the three was what I really liked-the war isn't bad or a chore by any means but it's really just not where I found the meat of the gameplay to be. Now that governing my planetary budget is forcibly automated there's nothing to DO. Even the vaunted (and very fun, I might add) player-created starships have gotten hit by this change-now that you can no longer put 100% of a planet's outcome into military production all the player-made ships are too expensive to produce in any kind of reasonable timeframe. TL;DR:the meat of the gameplay was almost entirely removed in a patch, game is boring now.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												Thre are definitly parts of this game I enjoy emensly but there are others that make this a struggle to play, particullarly the longer the game goes on. My biggest complaint is the level of micormanagement that is NECCESSARY in order to play this game. There are several things in the games that *should* releive the level of micromanagement, but they don't work how you would like. There is a global production governence that allows you to drive your indistry, but having one item for your entire empire makes things difficult. if you are primarily working on research, newer planets suffer when they could be building up their infrastructure, and provide fulfilling help to the empire, but instead being on the global governence they will contribute a pitence of research and almost never build up their infristructure. prior to 1.4 each planet could have its own governence but this became a nightmare of micromanagement when you had a large number of planets. they created an interesing  "in-between" that allows you to divirert things but in my opinion it is not enough to help balence things where they were before.The game has the ability to rely on the provided ai to assist with some of the micomanagement, however the AI is horible. It builds things almost at random, and the ship designs are just as worse. Last complaint is the space stations. it takes roughly 35 constor modules to fully build up a space station. the AI will only create constructors with only one construcotor modules, but with some work ones with 10+ modules can be created but it requires you to specifically send them roughout the univers instead of using the "oh so conviennt" request constructor button, which only uses the base constuctor. So instead of creating 2 ships for a fully build base it requires the 35. These are my biggest complaints. Overall though I enjoy the game as it is nice and relaxing. I just hate the 10 minutes I spend every turn directing my ships and orginizing my planets. If they can fix these things I will change my review but overall I give it an (7/10).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												((updated December 2015))I really enjoy playing this game, there's a lot in there that's a lot of fun to play with... The research, the production, the ship designing and creating your own factions... There's a LOT in this game that's a lot of fun.The problem is though, there's a lot of issues as well. Everytime I try to set up a multiplayer game, me and my brother end up having to set up games over and over usually around 3 - 4 times because one of us will be randomly disconnected before the start of the game.Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. We love playing with mods, and for a game like this, having mods gives an endless supply of changes and tweaks that can make the game more fun, the only problem is.... They can't be used multiplayer.It's disheartening when new 'content' is released for 5 dollars that seems to only break the game further, where many comments point out that yeah, it's fine that new stuff is released, but when the system is already buggy, these new systems add only more bugs and problems.Please just fix the game first, get multiplayer running smoothly, get mod support for multiplayer, right now if you look online, you barely see any games being hosted and those that do (I've been in a few and just asked about it) are from people who already know eachother... Noone is hosting games to find random players because the system is so unbelievably bad for setting something like that up.If you join a room, you know nothing about the game, about the selected win conditions, about the planet and universe settings, you just have to jump in blind... Who wants to jump in blind in the hopes of getting into a good game... The amount of times I've hosted a game and a random player joined only to leave when they found out what the game speed was set on, or the galaxy map, or any other part.It needs a better interface for multiplayer, more information that is given to joining players so they know (maybe even beforehand) what they are joining, instead of just hoping for a good game somehow.The game is fun, a lot of fun even, but the systems, the interface all make sure that multiplayer is a gruelling experience you only want to step into if you have people you know very well to play with.I plan on playing this game a lot more, especially multiplayer, but untill mod support is given, I cannot buy any expansion and add more content when the content that is there sometimes barely works as is.((Update))So, a couple of months have passed and though the UI has had some fixes and improvements, the game itself is still riddled with issues, multiplayer games still crash and Epic events are still not available for multiplayer games.I still keep on trying, because the game has a lot of potential, but it seems to be bogged down by technical issues that aren't being adressed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												I regret buying this game. Why?(Firstly, not one image in the videos is from actual game footage. Do not be deceived. This game relies on marketing to sell it. If you knew what I knew, you would not buy this game as it is broken in terms of functioning code and game design).Ok, some points about my game experience:(you can check every point in the game and they are all factual events. My opinion is not fact but it reflects my observence of these facts in the game)1 - Crashes every 15-30 minutes on insane mode due to memory leaks. I know it's memory leaks because there are arrays being created but not deleted or reused. Too much data is being accumulated somewhere and it results in the game becoming increasingly slower and slower and finally crashing and instantly going to desktop and closes the game. You will have a new appreciation for saving your progress between autosaves when you have long periods of time per turn before the next auto-save. Especially if you just spent 20 minutes cleaning out obsolete units to try and help the game become faster.----------2 - The space battles look ok at first but after a while you'll notice that it looks like all the spaceships are controlled by drunk drivers who love nothing better than to fly around like a dead goldfish in a whirlpool. This happens as they get closer and the maker seems to have a bad sense of what looks acceptable.----------3 - Sound often crashes. To overcome this flaw in coding: the music must be turned off and then back on - don't ask me why but it fixes the sound error. Sometimes the game will become unresponsive but not crash and return to windows. When you can no longer interact with anything, just save your current game in a new slot and re-load your game.----------4 - Computer AI cheats. I have it's bases totally surrounded and it magically creates armies and bases out of nothing in the middle of nowhere. Then the AI will tell me it surrenders and yet I still have to kill it anyway. Don't know if this is a bug or the game designer has a twisted idea of the word 'surrender'. Seriously, cheating is a last ditch effort for programmers who cannot make adaptive AI.----------5 - the game should be fun but I found it more tedious than my previous job doing data entry of government records OR data entry for Toyota.Why would I say this? There are few shortcuts to do anything in the game. You cannot mass delete, mass rally to a location, or even mass select other than stacking and making a fleet. There are no checkboxes or CTRL+Select to make selective deletion possible. You have to do many things individually and honestly this game felt more like a horrible job except that I'm the one paying to do it.... The hotkeys mentioned online do not work in most cases. "Y" works for yes, the working hotkeys are visible in tooltips but the online suggestions mostly do not work.----------6 - Just when you thought you were moving a slider to look at ships in a list, the tooltip blocks most of the list so you cannot even see what you are looking at.----------7 - the icons on the minimap are single pixels. Yes, you heard correctly, single pixels!!! Get ready for purple dot units on a purple background for it's team color. THe minimap is so bad I wanted to vomit, eat my vomit, poop it out, eat it again and vomit it again. It will provide hours of frustration as you squint to see wtf you are looking at. Also ship icons in groupings are impossible to recognize because they are just reduced scale images of large pictures. This results in "WTF is that?" moments and you have to then open up another menu to see what is what.And I'm using a 24" screen 1900x1200 and the minimap is still terrible. Same color for ships on same color for your area of control....so bad....high school art class FTW...----------8 - The production and rally points are so messy that you'll find half your army hidden in buildings that you never intended them to be in.----------9 - I make games for a living and so that's partly why I'm so critical. However the game does have it's promising moments but most likely you'll be forcing yourself to play because you paid 40~70 dollars depending on what country you live in. I paid 70 :(----------10 - The game just isn't fun at all - that's my final opinion after I completed an 'insane size map' that took me 20 hours+ (probably another 2 hours if I include the lost time due to crashes). ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Conclusion:----------Strategy:The only strategy really is to look at what weapons your enemy's ships have, what armor they have, and then choose the best rock, paper, scissor effect to win fights. The technology you choose should support how you want to play. Influence to steal bases, Friendly to win an alliance win, military to win fights and research to help you get an edge in whatever style you choose. Research alone will not win the game unless you choose that goal.----------Creativity:If you want to be creative in this game, you'll be very sad. The game has little opportunity for creativity and any startrek / starwars fetishes you have will be crushed when you see the ships floating like dead goldfish in a whirlpool. Yes, you can make spaceships with existing parts however the spaceships update so much and the game is so repetitive AND the battle scenes are so horrible that your art will be spat on by the current game design.----------Reward System:The main rule is that the inefficient player will lose to the AI. So your first few games will be hard but once you have those "ah~~~I see " moments where you realise how to beat the AI, you'll finish it easily but it will just take lots of time.Lack of patience is punished in this game.----------User Interface:Patience is also punished because this game makes you a full time data entry person thanks to a useless user interface (UI) which only caters for short games where the structure and unit count is smaller. When you have like 400 of these, the game's UI fails and just shows a blank screen beyond about 200 units in the list. Really helpful when the spaceship you want is at the bottom of the list and the filters don't move it to the top.----------Price and Music:Sorry to be critical but that's the way I am. I paid $70 for the game and I expected a $70 game but this seems more like a fancy prototype / alpha game. I wouldn't call it a beta because it was so buggy I really imagine the programmer to be inexperienced and not an eye for detail or design principles. Art is average but I'm very critical. Oh, and Music is AWFUL...thank goodness for 3rd party music players. Really, really depressing music with no passion in it.----------Closing Thoughts:Once again, sorry for being so critical but I earned that right when I paid $70 for a game that would have been fair if it was sold for $20~25Now when I read the following quote:"You must be running 64-bit Windows 7 or later to play Galactic Civilizations III. This requirement allows us to create the largest, most advanced, strategy game possible."- I believe this translates into:"You need 64-bit because my coding is so bad that a 32 bit OS will fail very quickly because I can't clean arrays or debug my game. In other words, I'll break through my lack of coding skill by using your 64 OS to extend the life of my memory leaks."----------Lesson Learned:I learned what kind of game design is less effective. This in turn helped me become a better game programmer. I'd avoid this game like the plague until the price comes down. Too late for me, can't be bothered reversing the transaction and having my Steam account limited until they work out why I reversed the bank transaction.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Played 4 games on immense galaxy - total play time approx 80 hours.   Game is an improvement over Gal Civ IIThe research tree is better in that it is not laid out from the start - but you discover it.  Bigger maps = bettersuggested improvements - (1) Bring back miners on astroids as a way to increase planet production (2) Rebalance cost of producing ships - at game start the colony ship costs 58 to 62 turns ,  quickly it becomes 300 to 500 turns which kills the game - possible solution - allow players to build older models of ship designs  the old M-1 Colony would be cheeper but slower and less range which is fine. (3)  The special perks (items) that a few of the planets have - tool tips need to better describe their effect if any (4) On the "manage planet" screen and the Manage starbase" screen - let the small map that normally appears in the upper right that shows the whole known galaxy and the individual planet/starbase location on it appear -  location may mean different selections for actions - and on turns where I start 2 planets or 2 starbases it is difficult to know which is which (5) Let the operator (game player) give names to rally points - the computer generated names are not helpful  (6)  Some of the color selections are difficult to see  -  insufficient contrast  -  example the yellow box in the galaxy screen that is usually in the upper right of the screen.  Yellow is a goos contrasting color but the pixel width of the lines in that screen renders it invisible (7) In the tactical battles - give the player options of say (a) all ships shoot at enemy ship closest to them or (b) all ships shoot at most dangerious ship in weapons range or (c) ?? (8) Create a on line game instruction book - that at lease gives the basics.Thanks for making a good game - and hope you are able to continue its evolution.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												I've enjoyed playing but was a little disappointed it is not deeper in terms of strategy and solar systems. Planetary invasion is over simple and it's hard not to succeed in a ground invasion. Various aliens are not really very unique. Planetary defenses aren't worth putting effort into as invasions suceed anyway. Orbital spacecraft are a race attribute "Paranoid" rather than technology and deliberately building planetary defenses. You can learn to put fighters on carriers but for some reason this doesn't translate into planet based fighters. Still very fun. But it could be great with a little effort. I have noticed it's alot more challenging if you disable technology trading.

												great game - some current problems.In a large galaxy with many planets the micromanagement of the planets becomes extremely tedious.Starbases surrounding planets (think 4 per planet) also need to be micromanaged and there is no automation.The lack of any sort of configurable auto-management system is kind of killing this game for me right now.After this current game I'm planing I'll probably quit playing Galactic CIV III because of this issue... the game becomes a boring click fest to micro manage... and it's repetitive.That said, the game is fantastic otherwise. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												This is amazing. If you are a fan of GC2, man oh man, you should own this. A lot of people would say that this game doesn't innovate enough, and there may be some value to their opinion. This is basically the same game, putting in a new and interesting campaign, polished up with nice graphics, with extra layers put in. Adjacency bonuses are one of the few new things in the game, a simple addition, but the fact that it makes you think about the layout of each of your planets, tickles something in me. It is a big step up from OG GC2 though, maintaining most of the innovations from the completed effort of both expansion packs. So if you go into it expecting a groundbreaking new game, you will be disappointed. But if you are a fan of the game, and can appreciate a completely rebuilt engine, polishing up what you loved for 2015. This is the game for you. *Sidenote* I invested 100$ in the elite founders pack. I know something like this is always a risk, but I am willing to bet on the company that bought us dark avatar, and twilight of the arnor. So that's it. I hope that you are enjoying the game like I am.

												Nice update for the series, Pro1. Streamlined version of GalCiv 2 2. Enhanced ship designer - and automatic ship designs if you can't be bothered ! 3. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												A great addition to the series.  With the ability to not simply use the mainstream factions, but actually completely make your own and the ships to go with them, this is what I've been looking for in a space-based 4X game.  And this doesn't even include the cinematic battles. While they don't have the tactical challenge of Empire at War's space combat, it is still quite a sight to see (or not see) your creations do combat with villains from all the way back to the original game.  Add to that a workshop full of ship designs and factions that other people are sharing and it can really capture just how big space is.  So get the game, play it and try to prove just how great the creatures of your imagination are.

												Yeah I like the game and it's worth getting if you like this sort of genre. There are a few problems I've found personally: for a start it's sometimes dificult to see which planets are mine, making them stand out more on the map would fix it. Secondly an enemy can win, which just happened to me, and I have no idea how. It's also possible to buy ships from an ally in exchange for technology, then use their own ships to invade them. :) You can also bankrupt an enemy, as I did, by buying loads of ships from allies then gift them to an enemy, the upkeep then destroys their econimy XD. Personally I focus on food, growth and science, I also focus on one thing at a time normally... the mechanics are more or less fine, it's really just the interface which I dislike because like I said finding things like my ships, planets and star bases can be tricky.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												If you were a fan of Galactic Civlizations II, you will love Galactic Civilizations III.It seems to have everything the other game had, with all the annoying bits taken out. Starbase management no longer feels like a chore and the alien creator is much better, allowing you to create your own races of aliens and give guidelines for their personalities.The strong RPG element of the game is still there, with a very complex system of diplomacy. The computer opponents don't simply try to defeat you and each other; they can be assigned general personalities. The many paths to victory also allows the player much flexibility in style.Also, I give credit to Stardock for always abiding by strong standards and providing beautiful finished products. The battle simulator is extremely fun to watch, especially with large fleets. Play is intuitive, but complex.In short, I found it to be a beautiful, fun product that no fan of the genre will want to be without.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												GC3 is a solid step forward in 4X gaming. As of late summer 2015, the game has a few rough edges which could use polishing (sub-optimal path plotting while moving units and stale UI panel components are probably the biggest 2 for me right now). However, Stardock has released updates recently addressing other flaws, indicating this not EA style abandonmed-ware. Most importantly:  the fundamentals foundation of GC3 appears stout. At the risk of sounding like a fan-boy, my assessment is this is currently the premier turn based strategy game on the market. This game supports the requisite feature set and strategic warfare dynamics I expect out from this genre, which the forefunner competitor's latest generation of titles should have but do not.Kudos to Stardock for finding a working formula, sticking with it, and judiciously knowing how far to go with incremental evolution.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												Galactic Civilizations 3 is certainly a good game in its current stage; however, I don't feel like it's currently worth its hefty price tag. If you're someone who strives to stay ahead in Technology, expect an uneventful start. I didn't get pulled into a war until ~400 turns in, which means I was just improving buildings for about two hours straight. Going to war early doesn't feel worth it since it costs so many credits to upgrade your ships to the latest version. AIs seem to have a static personality for now, which means every game they'll act exactly the same way (Krynn always seem to hate me no matter what). Unlike Civilization, where you can own a single city and still manage to win on even the hardest difficulty, expanion is a must here. But, to combat this, colonizing new planets does NOT affect your overall happiness as it does in Civ. The combat system is just beautiful. Cinematic views of battles are amazing, and feel very rewarding if you're on the winning side. Likewise, the cinematics throughout the game feel polished and rewarding; whether it's colonizing your first planet or building your first starbase, the game makes it feel like an actual accomplishment. If you have money to blow, get this game. If not, wait for a sale. Though the game is lacking a bit right now, as most 4X games do when they're new, I trust that it will continue to expand, and eventually justify its price tag.

												1) The UI in this games needs work. Look at GC2 you could organize Fleets, Planets, Starbases much better than this game.  This game is larger than GC2 which means it is currently an organizual (sp?) nightmare.  I perfer to play on the largest maps with a large number of factions. I usally have no desire to play on the smaller maps.2) The AI is not very good in this game GC2 seems to have a better AI (I still play it from time to time.) 3) I play a lot of MP and SP and the MP needs to be able to play on the largest map sizes and be able to select Pirates as we can in the SP game. In fact we should be able to have all the same options in MP as we do in SP.  My friends and I love to play MP on the largest map possible and we really want to play on Immense size maps.4) The Ship editor is great but it would be nice if we can attach ship designs to certain factions where only that faction gets them as default. For Example, I would like to attach Sar Trek Federation ships to the faction, The Federation. So that when they are played either by a player or AI they use only those ships. 5) The game does have a lot of potential and there are some cool stuff in it however some of the things above need to be addressed. Escpecially the AI.  6) Now I know this won't happen but what would really make this game awsome is putting in an OPTION for tactical space battles. It is a shame (and this can be said for all the GC titles) that you have this awsome ship designer yet we cannot control these ships in battle.  Now I would perfer full control but any control would be better than just watching a movie.

												A graphically updated version of GCiv II, with an AI that is a bit more complex.  If you were a fan before,  you will enjoy this game.  If you have never played in this sandbox, the micro-management may seem daunting, but this is the perfect empire building game that will give you a sense of accomplishment after 30 minutes, yet keep you playing for hours.  The tech tree is a little less intuitive than before, but new additions to it make this change more interesting than troublesome.  Space Battles are all about blending the right gear to best your opponent.  while land battles have been extremely streamlined, making this part of the game flow much quicker.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												Great 4X game, very diversified tech tree requiring careful weighing of what you need and when. I've explored this game quite a bit and still I see myself getting back to this game in the future. Diplomacy and tech trading is important too, it's not just something you can ignore, so that's nice. Combat is simplified but the different weapon types and tech choices you have to make keep the tension on early on. Overall, I'd recommend this game without hesitation, and I should add that you don't need a total beast of a computer to play on pretty huge maps, the game remains stable and running smoothly. The one thing that could be improved is with (micro)managing planets. It works perfectly when you have 10 planets at the start of a game, but it gets annoying once you start conquering neighbours and terraforming your planets, and it's just a total pain when you're going for a conquest victory with 100+ planets. Maybe a macromanager for planets, beyond production / science / money levels, with a build order that could be customized and applied?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												GalCiv 3 is a turn-based strategy game where you start off with three ships and a single planet and go on to explore and strive to prosper in a galaxy as immense and interesting as you choose to make it. It plays similar to Sid Meier's Civilization, but with so many controllable variables that you literally can set the features to only include what you enjoy and turn off whatever annoys you. Unless you just don't like turned based 4x games at all, it's pretty much impossible not to love this one.If you are a fan of the series, you will enjoy GC3 for the same reasons as its predecessors. It's very much the same game with a few new wrinkles and augmentations that fit comfortably into the formula and leave the core look and feel intact. In fact my one complaint about GalCiv 3 is that I was expecting, and hoping for, a more dramatic improvement in the production values. Apparently, most of the new features that made 64 bit processing a requirement for this game have to do with things like unbelievably large maps and not so much with making the experience seem more realistic and immersive in the course of normal play. It must be said that you get absolutely gorgeous detail (and excellent sound effects) when you zoom in tight on a ship, or a world, or even a star or junk planet. But you can't actually PLAY up close like that, and at the zoom level you'll have to use for everything but combat, GC3 still looks and feels like a 2D board game with 1990s graphics, with ships, planets, and resources reduced to crude icons and the overlay destroying the sense of being in outer space. That's heartbreaking when the components look so 3D, realistic, and beautiful close up.Speaking of combat -- as in previous GalCivs and even more so in this edition, the space battle graphics and sound are near motion picture quality, and in that sense aesthetically satisfying. I was disappointed however to find no improvement at all from GalCiv 2 in terms of the visual perspective you are provided from which to see this eye candy. If you choose the "Cinematic" setting, you'll see slick, wonderful pans, cuts, and strafing views similar to watching a movie, but as often as not they don't show the action you're interested in -- for instance, you might get a shot that revolves around the starbase you're attacking without showing any of your ships. The Top Down view is better from a tactical perspective, but it's not particularly immersive and if like me you design your spacecraft to look best in profile, as they are shown in every sci-fi movie, TV show, book cover, and derivative art form, watching them from straight overhead is unsatisfying. You'd think the "Free" view would provide whatever perspective you want to see, and it can -- but it's so cumbersome to adjust that by the time you line up the ship(s) you want to focus on at the angle that's most pleasing to look at, the fight is over. It should also be pointed out, if you don't already know, that GalCiv battles are spectate-only -- you design and deploy your ships with meticilous control, but during an actual battle you have no input whatsoever -- none. It would be nice to have some options such as focusing fire on a particular enemy ship or turning one of your damaged shields away from the line of fire, or even an option to attempt retreat if a fight is going badly. This is not as frustrating as it probably sounds, and probably some future GC rendition will experiment with limited battle control. For now though, it's completely hands-off.But these observations are offered for clarity only and in no way diminish my enthusiastic endorsement of this game. The GalCiv games are true classics -- a joy to play for any strategy gamer, and particularly if you're into the space setting. And, happily, GC3 doesn't do anything to screw that up. It's the best installment yet in terms of customization, and you can easily make it into a Star Trek game, or Star Wars, or Farscape, or Firefly, or any other Sci-Fi mythos you're into. Custom ships are fun and easy to create with the huge assortment of parts and the best design tools of any game ever, and putting Captain Picard or Han Solo at the helm in place of the game's stock characters is just a download away. I would like to see the series evolve into state of the art presentation at some point -- but in the mean time, I'll keep on playing GalCiv as one of my everpresent sandbox games just because it is so damned fun. It's got that 4x "just one more turn" appeal in spades, and its replayability is essentially without limit. If you're considering this game at all -- get it. You won't be sorry. :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												This is a good game. In order to make this a helpful review I'll review different points below.Good stuff:------------- The game has interesting races to choose from and in addition has excellent functions for you to make your very own custom race including; racial traits, different leader/race pictures, starting system planetary setup and so on.- Excellent automation options. You can set rally points and many other parameters for ALL shipyards, and so on, via a very simple and fast menu, no hassle at all to manage a sprawling empire.- Very good ship customization. This isn't something I use as I lack the patience for it, but if you like to decide how your ships should look then you can spend a LOT of time in the ship builder!- Nice cutscenes and pictures when you colonize and gain resources. I'd like more of them though since they set the tone and atmosphere in the game. - Not all planets are equal. Some planets will have more/less building space than others. You CAN develope them so they can house more imprevements, but only to a degree. I like this, this makes planets different and you would do well to protect your more precious planets. - Space battles. I actually like that you have no direct control over battles. I'm the leader of the nation, not the admiral in the fleet. - Bad stuff: (Some of this stuff is more about my own personal preferance rather than objectively negative things)------------- The game could have used more immersion than it currently has. Perhaps more specific and different UI:s or so. - For me personally the mid game turns much into a click fest where I just press "next turn". I suspect that this has to do with me playing too passively and too peacefully. - I'm also not a fan of how planets are developed. Buildings of the same type give proxomity bonii to buildings of the same type. This is a true and tried mechanic but, without being able to give an example of a  "better" system, I would have liked a different logistics systems. - Space battles. This is my first GC game so I have no idea how battles were modelled before. But battles look a little silly. Ships bump into each other and circle/wobble around each other in a drunken fashion making the ships look like little rubber toys rather than advanced warships engaging in deadly space battles.

												This game like many other 4x games is very addictive. Its great fun and you always want to do just one more turn. The ship designer is very good and you can create just about any ship you have seen in sci-fi movies as well as design your own look. You can create and design your own race and decide what bonuses or penalties your race should have from a number of options.There are a few things that annoy me though. Diplomacy could use a bit more work. The AI has no respect for your borders. You can't destroy their ships inside your borders without declaring war. You can't warn the AI to stay out of your borders or demand that the AI remove a star base inside your borders the AI can however request that you remove yours inside their borders.While I really like the control you have and how much you can micro manage your empire this becomes a chore when you have say 25 or more planets. I would like to be able to make a template for the planets window where I set core buildings for an industrial planet, core buildings for a science planet, core buildings for economy planets and core buildings for a bread basket.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Ok i put into a ton of hours into the game even more the the origianl civilizations which is a great game as well. but besides that point of the review. what do i think of the game. well considering i put almost 200 hpurs into the game that can tell you everything about it.This game is a great space 4x strategy game. now what are thing that i like about the game.1. your can create a custom race. I loved the customization for the game you could practilly spend hours withot even playing the game and still have a ton of fun. make what you want. I created my own rce in the game and it's awsome. and the ship designer along with factions and the workshop incorporated in the game. that can bring some more replayablility due to custom faction and make thing like x wings from star wars, or the enterprise from star trek.2. the gameplay is solid. you have 8 races to play with their own uniqe traits and this can effect how you play and adds more time to replay value for the game. if your a fan of space/si-fi game this will be your dream game. running you very own empire the way you want and conquer the galaxy. A side note, I'd like to thank Angry Joe for streaming this game months ago, if it wasnt for that i would not be playing this game. the game is rich in content and feel just like an RPG, but in SPACE!Now what are some thing that disappointed me or didn't like1. No local Multiplayer but it does have online multiplayer so there that2. There were some issues (for me at least) that the game crashed somtime while loading the designer screen where you design ship i had that happen about 2 times so it does crash and have bugs3. the A.I. is a bit of a pushover if your playing on lower difficultys. and with that (and i can't comfirm that this happens on higher difficultys above normal) it lead to exploiting some things with the A.I. like wearing down opposing fleets that im at war with useing shipyards. So i would recommand you play on higher difficultys that is above normal. though it doesn't work all the tim but it can happen with smaller fleet sizes and having a tone of preduction to produce shipyards about every turn at will.4. the cainpain was surpisingly short there are three campain maps though it does make up for it in time with objectives and bigger maps. at least it's not 4 hours. at least i think it is.Now i would recommand this game but only if you like sitting at your compter for hours and have a beast machine and play for hours. if you have a low end pc it might not be the greatest thing to buy but once you get a better pc then get this game.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												Hi all just got done playing GCV 3 .. So i just wanna add my oppinion. first off yea typical 4x strategy on par with endless space yet feels as though you can take the upper hand early un unlike endless space which leaves you lagging all through the game right until you unlock the high tier stuff when you finally start to make a difference in gal ciiv 3 you can do this pretty early on which is goodthe down side is all races share the same technology and that for me makes the game dull and boring and removes the potential for replayability as other races.. it would be nice for once to have a game like this where each race is unique and has unique bonuses and their own technology and have it represented visualy in the game too.i love the customisation and again would be better with each races own personal tech and research. all in all a good 4x strat and works great at its core as a strategy game.   so yea defo worth buying.. thew final down side is having to pay again for DLC... im not a big fan of paying twice three times let alone four times for the same product ..   if you buy a game that should include all updates with it.. not to be resold to us later on !!! it seems like we have paid for half a game.  so yea not impressed with that aspect.  and certainly will not be paying for DLC which should be included in the game. i concider this to be theft. and will not be a victim of it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Review as of v1.4:I am a big fan of Galciv 2 and this game hits that Galciv feeling. I have no hesitation in recommending this game to 4x players. The game is really good, no question.The devs have made a lot of progress since release; and 1.4 is a big improvement for the ai - for me most notably is that the ai won't spam starbases everywhere anymore.My fav things:- tech tree is so much better than galciv2- nebulae and other stellar background (like black holes)- strategic resources- ship designer - it is insanely good- building on planets is beautiful, smooth and satisfying (especially the adjacency mechanic - making this nicely strategic)Issues:- still buggy in places (but have never had a full on crash). Two bugs for me are that the ai spams messages which are clearly not relevant; and some information doesn't refresh straight away creating some genuine confusion as to what is happening.- feature light-ish (this is only a comment in relation to galciv 2, it still has a great many features). I'm sure expansions will correct this and go beyond galciv 2; as it stands in no way is galciv 3 an incomplete game.- small payable dlc ... why are these things not in base game kinda thingSummary:Gameplay is unquestionably fun, the world is immersive, the sound design is great and the ai is a challenge. This is a good 4x game and I look forward to further patches, development and of course the three planned expansions.Go buy.EDIT: forgot to say how awesome the multiplayer is, smooth and crisp. The game is also 64 bit which is a massive step up from galciv 2 creating what I can only describe as a brilliant play experience with no lag experienced yet.

												The game has a steep learning curve, especially on bigger maps. I have had no major issues running the game on an older machine. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												Ok, there are some negative reviews, and their issues are not wrong. On large maps the game rapidly becomes clunky and very time consuming. Micro-management of every little issue can bog turns down a bit if you are a bit of a perfectionist. I play games to have fun however. So I just build whatever I need to keep my empire going and tweak it as I go along. That means I don't get bogged down. I would probably be thrashed in a multiplayer by an optimiser. However my turns take 5 minutes as opposed to their half hour turns and I am having more fun. ^_^A nice big, heavily detailed turn based sci-fi strategy game with excellent race customisation, good ship construction, nicely sized tech trees and the possibility for galaxy maps that feel like they are an actual galaxy. The game does not lag too badly even on the largest maps. The automated battles run pretty well and look fantastic!I like this game quite a bit and would recommend it. The $50 price tag is a little too high and yes, it crashes sometimes (in particular when generating a new map it will sometime CTD). The UI does take a lot of clicking back and forward when fiddling with production and taxation settings. However if you are patient it is worth it. :)Check it out. :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Watching this one move through development is my prime example of how Early Access should happen. Solid concept, great (in every sense of the word) developers, implementation of complex features and ideas, all of which have really, really come together with Beta 6. Riddle me impressed.The game's fun and offers a decent step up from GalCiv2, maintaining many of the features that make the series familiar but with many very welcome revamps of several mechanics (resources are a big one) which breathe fresh air into this galactic-scale empire-building 4x series. The well-thought-out mechanics sheer hard work put into the game have turned it from a humorous shell of a demo into a truly polished product.Be warned, this game, as its predecessors and a few of its contemporaries, suffers badly from "one more turn" syndrome. Please finish your homework, children, and watch the time or you'll easily find yourself playing until sunrise.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was introduced into the Galactic Civilizations franchise with number 2 quite a few years ago and I was astonished at how such a great title had slipped past my love of strategy games for so long. I had played it almost too death but then its expansions Dark Avatar and Twilight of the Arnor brought new life and experiences too an already vibrant universe and I once again plunged into the expansive galactic scene in great enjoyment.With the announcement of the third title you can make a good guess how exited I was too re-enter this universe and couldn't wait too lose myself in it again.I may not have too many hours currently on record but believe me that will most likely change quickly and so far I'll say the game does not disappoint. It's presentation and graphics are beautiful but as any good video games player knows, good graphics does not always define a good game. The expansive ship designer has made a gallant return and has been adjusted for easier access for new players and greater creativity for more experienced players. Of course the feature that  Gal Civ has been well praised for is it's shear capacity to let the player create the empire he wishes too with no restrictions whether it be an empire founded and risen by war,trade,culture,diplomacy and others ways.There are a few technical bugs which are caused by either the game and/or the rig your playing on but that's too be expected and I'm sure will be addressed accordingly. However with an interesting single player story and a sandbox mode were absolutely anything can happen, strategy players with minds set on conquering the heavens in anyway they desire will not be let down with Galactic Civilizations III.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												A turn-based strategy game on a galactic scale. The short of it is, Galactic Civilizations 2 with a more simple and smooth feeling tech tree (or tech trees as the case is) which keeps the same capacity for user-created vessels and races.Pros:-Galactic Scale turn based strategy-Customization to a reasonable extent without any need for modding-Variable degrees of AI difficulty-Honestly the graphics are quite lovely zoomed in, even if you'll usually have to zoom out to see things overall.Cons:-Game can feel 'slow', even for a turn-based strategy-Tech trees can still be tedious to work through-Random planet generation often likes to place tiles and upgrades in nonsensical places (Even homeworlds are random)-Units turn pretty insane pretty rapidly once you hit a certain tech level, and often those units will utterly annihalate things like starbases that may have taken 50+ turns to build up in the blink of an eye.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												Why did you remove the planet production wheel?Why is it not even an option anymore?Why did you think it was a good idea to change such a large gameplay element when it's not in alpha (or even beta for that matter) anymore?With it's removal you've just promoted improvement spam, made the game needlessly long and made it a requirement that planets manufacture and research constantly, otherwise it's wasting raw production.And yes I know that currently I am talking about an update that is in beta (not that it matters, major gameplay changes shouldn't be done in beta), but the developers have been talking about removing the wheel for a while. With the next mandatory update the planet production wheel will be gone.This game has been ruined.Edit:The main game has been updated, the planet production wheel has been officially removed.Edit [5/11/15]:Despite the dev being arsey about it, the wheel is back:1. Opt into the 1.41 Beta.2. Run the game once.3. In 'prefs.ini' set 'UseColonyProductionWheel' to 1.As long as the wheel stays, my review stays positive.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												Galactic Civilizations III is a beautiful and well made 4x space empire managment game.  Having played MOO1, MOO2, Gal Civs 1,2 and now number 3, this is by far the most engaging and challenging game yet.________________________________________________________________Pros:   Very nice graphics all around.  Planets now show city lights on the dark side and the background is just beautiful.  Ships also really pop out.  Huge fleet battles looks really good!  The Ship Designer is top notch as always.  Plenty of options to make almost anything you can imagin.  A lot of nice fixes to diplomacy. Every race no longer DoW for no reason... except the Drengin but that's    expected.  The absolute huge size of the galaxy makes for some epic empire vs empire wars.  I only play on Insane size!  Civilization customization is well done and there are so many options to make the civilization of your dreams.  Steam Workshop support.  Makes up for the lack of starting civs by using the faction mods and can add some awesome looking ships to your game.  Lots of great work done by the community.  Continuing the story/campiegn from previous Gal Civs.  (That opening cutscene is just AWESOME!)____________________________________________________________Cons:    (As of this review) No planetary invasion cutscenes or otherwise some neat way of seeing your troops conquer the planet.  It all happens in the background instantly and is very anti-climatic.  This is something that was in previous Gal Civs but not in this one and it is a little bit of a let down.  I hold out hope that Stardock will add it in either by patch or DLC.  Needs some better management/organization options for fleets.  Whenever you add a ship to a fleet it changes the fleets name to some random number with your factions name.  For me the naming of fleets is important so I can at a glance of the list tell where certain fleets are without cycling though all of them. This can get annoying when upgrading ships you will need to change the fleet name each time you add the ship back into fleet.  When I have 50+ Fleets of various sizes and purposes running around, trying to remember which ones I named what can get frustrating.   Though civilizations will not DoW as much I still have the unbelieveable occurence of some civs (Drengin mostly) DoW even if they are not even remotly in range of my empire to fight/invade.  So it is a war in name only.  The AI bu now should be able to take into account the distance of it's empire to the one it wants to DoW.  When you make another Civ know you want to destroy them they tend to prepare for you and this kind of removes the possablility of being attacked by suprise (ex: Peral Harbor style)   AI Behavior in general:  The AI can behave in some strange ways and seems to lack proper skills to manage their own planets.  I tend to find their planets near rebellion or under developed.  I then find it strange to see with such poor managment how they can afford fleets of such epic size.  In fact I would say AI behavior is the biggest flaw in this game._________________________________________________________Conclusion:  Depsite the cons, which are in my opinion really kinda minor when it comes to the rest of this game,  Galactic Civilizations III is one of the very top 4x strategy games on the market at this very moment.  Very engaging and beautiful, I tip my hat to you Stardock... well done.  I look forward to see what else you bring to this game and series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												I've been playing Galactic Civilizations from the start of the series.  Fans of the earlier titles are likely to enjoy this iteration.  Most of the core ideas are well-implemented, and the look of the game is appropriately updated.  Particular highlights include a more diverse body of random events (even before obtaining the Mega Events DLC), an ideological system, race-specific tech trees, and an incredibly nuanced ship designer.  Of course, there is robust support for custom-designed content, which should proliferate as the playerbase grows.For people unfamiliar with the series, Galactic Civilizations is about competitive empire-building.  In the standard game, a player begins with a spacefaring race still limited to its homeworld.  Simultaneously managing exploration, settlement, economic development, technological growth, and security concerns; the aim is to colonize distant worlds and thrive.  Victory conditions often include peaceful options like diplomacy or even transcending physical existence itself, though violent conquest is also on the list.  Managing large happy colonies provides the resources to attempt the loftiest goals.Having played many games in this 4X genre, I feel Galactic Civilizations III strikes a nice balance between accessibility and complexity.  It is possible to control every detail right down to the placement of decorative fins on warships, but delegating to the AI to focus on high-level questions and strategic command is also a viable approach.  I don't yet have enough experience to have a strong opinion about the AI, but I find the normal difficulty setting suitable for learning the ropes.  Ideology is a particular treat, giving significant consequence to the morality of crucial choices.  For players willing to put in the time a serious strategy game demands, Galactic Civilizations III should provide many hours of pleasant satisfaction.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												I do recommend the game for those that played 1 and 2 or any of the Civilzation style games and liked them.  I did find some of the extreme times on research a bit tedious and I did find the income remains a bit too slow to develop.  I don't want to spend forever on the larger galaxies and that IS what it ends up feeling like when you make the research trees and income take that long while making the game start out at ridiculous sublight technology levels.  Too slow to develop and way too economically pinched to remain fun for any but the most devoted.  If you choose to cater to the extremists in this regard you will lose too many of the casuals.  I love this genre and I loved so much about this game other than the slow research trees and restrictively slow economic growth.  That being said my son, brother and best friend all played it once and I think the reiterated quote was "It's no Masters of Orion"  although they did admit to my defense of the wonderful new ideas, expansive ship design and beautiful graphics.  You lost every one of them with one or both of my stated issues.  Myself, I like it albeit with the caveat of those issues.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Played 4 games on immense galaxy - total play time approx 80 hours.   Game is an improvement over Gal Civ IIThe research tree is better in that it is not laid out from the start - but you discover it.  Bigger maps = bettersuggested improvements - (1) Bring back miners on astroids as a way to increase planet production (2) Rebalance cost of producing ships - at game start the colony ship costs 58 to 62 turns ,  quickly it becomes 300 to 500 turns which kills the game - possible solution - allow players to build older models of ship designs  the old M-1 Colony would be cheeper but slower and less range which is fine. (3)  The special perks (items) that a few of the planets have - tool tips need to better describe their effect if any (4) On the "manage planet" screen and the Manage starbase" screen - let the small map that normally appears in the upper right that shows the whole known galaxy and the individual planet/starbase location on it appear -  location may mean different selections for actions - and on turns where I start 2 planets or 2 starbases it is difficult to know which is which (5) Let the operator (game player) give names to rally points - the computer generated names are not helpful  (6)  Some of the color selections are difficult to see  -  insufficient contrast  -  example the yellow box in the galaxy screen that is usually in the upper right of the screen.  Yellow is a goos contrasting color but the pixel width of the lines in that screen renders it invisible (7) In the tactical battles - give the player options of say (a) all ships shoot at enemy ship closest to them or (b) all ships shoot at most dangerious ship in weapons range or (c) ?? (8) Create a on line game instruction book - that at lease gives the basics.Thanks for making a good game - and hope you are able to continue its evolution.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Galactic Civilizations III is a wonderful 4x space strategy game. If you like these types of game you will not be disappointed.  I have played these 4x space strategy games since masters of orion. New elementes were added which truely improved upon this genre. Such differing tile bonus dependent on the planet, special resources which are needed for specific upgrades to your ships, the spaceship creator is amazing, and the list of improvement from the old title continue. The epic maps that one can play now with excessive and insane is incredable. Warning dependent on your machine it may not be playable for theese huge galaxies.The weakest part of the game is the ai which has been improved upon since release which it needed. Diplomacy is a bit weak too however as you figure out the game you will be able to make peace with stronger military powers which some complain is impossible to do. I will tell you now it is not. Even if they are at war with you it is not very difficult to make peace if you have a lot of cash on hand. The learning curve of this type of game might be to great for someone who has never played a 4x space sandbox before but if you plug away you will find a path that works for you for Victory!

												A great addition to the series.  With the ability to not simply use the mainstream factions, but actually completely make your own and the ships to go with them, this is what I've been looking for in a space-based 4X game. While they don't have the tactical challenge of Empire at War's space combat, it is still quite a sight to see (or not see) your creations do combat with villains from all the way back to the original game.  Add to that a workshop full of ship designs and factions that other people are sharing and it can really capture just how big space is.  So get the game, play it and try to prove just how great the creatures of your imagination are.

												It's a pretty boring dissappointment which pains me to say as I've enjoyed the franchise over the years.The Good: Ship design - none betterTidy empire managementNostalgia/familiaritySteam workshopThe Bad:Graphics - it already looks oldCombat - it's uninspired and lifelessThe Campaign -  is a disgrace at 3 simple maps with next to no story, lore or caring.  DLC -  Death By a Thousand Cuts.  Stardock seems to think that they can run a beta for 2 years and charge for it.  Putting things in, taking things out and charging money for poor DLC that other companies throw around as junky freebies.  I don't care about the money, it's the content itself that's embarrassing.The Meh:Diplomacy/Trade UI - Ultra basic diplo and unsophisitcated trade UIPlanetary Building View - It looks old and is designed poorly.  Last I played you had to individually delete each unwanted ememy building seperately on newly captured planets instead of having a "delete all" option.  It doesn't sound like a big deal until you start rolling over multiple planets a turn and have to listen to the annoying buzzer sound it makes when deleting hundreds of buildings throughout a game.Tedious gameplaySadly it smacks of mobile game effort and is too boring to recommend.  Wait for Endless Space 2 or Stellaris or simply buy this on sale when it's all bundled.  What a dissappointment.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												Alright.  Now, I really want to like this game.  I have tried.  I have played hours of it, but the game simply does not do it for me.  Overall, the game mechanics, the content, the tech-tree, ships, etc. on offer is plenty and varied.  However, the game, for me is too much of a reskin of GC II, which is not to say that is a bad thing, but it would seem the developers did not aim to improve upon the old game with the new.My biggest gripe with GC III is the mundane, haphazard, and back-seated approach to combat.  There is virtually (if any at all) player interaction during combat.  The player assembles a fleet of ships, sends them against an enemy fleet and simply watches the combat unfold.  Of course, the player upgrades one's ships and develops military techology as a way to enhance the fighitng capacity and abilities, but in no way can one direct anything during combat in real time or in turn based.  This is a lost opportunity.  The devs could have really gone out and made combat interactive, and improved the old game systems with new mechanics in the new game.A general criticism, completely shrouded in my own subjective leanings, is that the game is not immersive at all.  The music, the environment, the galaxy, the races, and so on just feels bland.  I do not get any sense that the galaxy is a living and breathing arena filled with races, wars, trade, and diplomacy.  Of course, all of these things do happen, but there is no real sense of signicance from these interactions that gives me a sense of immersion.I would personally not recommend this game to those players wishing for a more interactive combat system.  However, the game overall offers enough content, graphical fidelity, and overall competence for me to give it a very, very lukewarm recommendation.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												A graphically updated version of GCiv II, with an AI that is a bit more complex.  If you were a fan before,  you will enjoy this game.  If you have never played in this sandbox, the micro-management may seem daunting, but this is the perfect empire building game that will give you a sense of accomplishment after 30 minutes, yet keep you playing for hours.  The tech tree is a little less intuitive than before, but new additions to it make this change more interesting than troublesome.  Space Battles are all about blending the right gear to best your opponent.  while land battles have been extremely streamlined, making this part of the game flow much quicker.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Ok i put into a ton of hours into the game even more the the origianl civilizations which is a great game as well. but besides that point of the review. what do i think of the game. well considering i put almost 200 hpurs into the game that can tell you everything about it.This game is a great space 4x strategy game. now what are thing that i like about the game.1. your can create a custom race. I loved the customization for the game you could practilly spend hours withot even playing the game and still have a ton of fun. make what you want. I created my own rce in the game and it's awsome. and the ship designer along with factions and the workshop incorporated in the game. that can bring some more replayablility due to custom faction and make thing like x wings from star wars, or the enterprise from star trek.2. the gameplay is solid. you have 8 races to play with their own uniqe traits and this can effect how you play and adds more time to replay value for the game. if your a fan of space/si-fi game this will be your dream game. running you very own empire the way you want and conquer the galaxy. A side note, I'd like to thank Angry Joe for streaming this game months ago, if it wasnt for that i would not be playing this game. the game is rich in content and feel just like an RPG, but in SPACE!Now what are some thing that disappointed me or didn't like1. No local Multiplayer but it does have online multiplayer so there that2. There were some issues (for me at least) that the game crashed somtime while loading the designer screen where you design ship i had that happen about 2 times so it does crash and have bugs3. the A.I. is a bit of a pushover if your playing on lower difficultys. and with that (and i can't comfirm that this happens on higher difficultys above normal) it lead to exploiting some things with the A.I. like wearing down opposing fleets that im at war with useing shipyards. So i would recommand you play on higher difficultys that is above normal. though it doesn't work all the tim but it can happen with smaller fleet sizes and having a tone of preduction to produce shipyards about every turn at will.4. the cainpain was surpisingly short there are three campain maps though it does make up for it in time with objectives and bigger maps. at least it's not 4 hours. at least i think it is.Now i would recommand this game but only if you like sitting at your compter for hours and have a beast machine and play for hours. if you have a low end pc it might not be the greatest thing to buy but once you get a better pc then get this game.
